chapter: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 1: Which one of the following pathological features has a higher risk of developing into invasive 
breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Atypical hyperplasia has a higher risk of developing into invasive breast carcinoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 2: A woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancers underwent genetic testing. She 
is found to have a BRCA1 gene mutation. Which of the following is she at risk of developing?
questions.explanation:
Individuals with BRCA1 mutations are likely to develop triple receptor-negative and 
high-grade breast carcinomas.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following does not increase the risk of breast carcinoma in women?
questions.explanation:
Early age of first pregnancy, breastfeeding, and multiparity are protective factors for carcinoma of 
the breast. This is due to a reduction in the overall number of ovulatory cycles thereby reducing 
the duration of estrogen's action on the breast tissues.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 4: The most common location of breast carcinoma is the

questions.explanation:
The upper outer quadrant of the breast has a greater volume of tissue and is the most common 
site of breast carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 5: A woman presented to the clinic with redness and itching over the left breast as shown in the 
image below. Histopathology showed large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the 
epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical picture and histology are suggestive of Paget's disease of the breast. Paget’s disease is a rare type of cancer involving the nipple-areolar complex, often with an 
underlying in-situ or invasive ductal carcinoma. It presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of 
the nipple which may progress to ulceration. Paget disease of the breast is often mistaken for 
eczema. A nipple biopsy specimen of Paget's disease will show a population of cells that are identical to the 
underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round 
or oval nuclei are pathognomonic for this condition. 210 
Sold by @itachibot Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or 
mastectomy. Paget's disease

questions.question: Question 6: Which is the most common variant of breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Invasive ductal carcinoma (not otherwise specified) is the most common variant of breast 
carcinoma. It is also known as infiltrating ductal carcinoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 7: 205 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not true regarding breast carcinoma?

options.a: Cutaneous oedema in inflammatory carcinoma is the result of blockage of the sub-dermal
options.b: Mucinous carcinomas are usually hormone negative
options.c: Calcifications are frequently associated with ductal carcinoma in situ
options.d: Lobular carcinoma in situ is multi centric and bilateral

questions.explanation:
211 
Sold by @itachibot Mucinous carcinoma is usually hormone-positive (90%). It is also called colloid carcinoma. It is a 
low-grade tumor with a good prognosis. It typically presents as a bulky mass in the elderly. Option A: Pathologic hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma is a painful, swollen breast, which is 
warm with cutaneous edema due to blockage of subdermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells. Option C: Calcification is usually associated with ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). It is the most 
common malignancy detected in screening mammograms. Option D: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is mainly multicentric (sometimes multifocal) and 
bilateral.

questions.question:
Question 8: Arrange the following subtypes of breast carcinomas according to the best to worst 
prognosis?
questions.explanation: Tubular carcinoma has the best prognosis. Inflammatory carcinoma has the worst prognosis. Order of breast carcinomas from best to worst prognosis: • Tubular carcinoma (Best prognosis) • Adenocystic • Cribriform carcinoma • Papillary carcinoma • Medullary carcinoma • Invasive lobular carcinoma • Invasive ductal carcinoma (NOS)* • Inflammatory carcinoma breast (Worst prognosis) NOS- Not otherwise specified
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 9: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 
days. On examination, there was local rise of temperature, and the swelling was mobile over 
the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive 
of inflammatory carcinoma of the breast. Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It mimics acute 
mastitis. The hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the 
dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin, often without a discrete underlying 
tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of 
the breast, warmth, erythema and edema. A breast lump may or may not be present. A diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly 
progressive swelling with inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging 
features with ultrasound and a mammograph is non-specific due to the underlying erythema and 
edema. A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment includes combined-modality treatment: 212 
Sold by @itachibot • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy • Mastectomy • Radiation therapy • Hormonal therapy- for ER-positive tumors • Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors Option B: Giant fibroadenomas occasionally occur during puberty. These are benign solid 
encapsulated slow-growing tumors over 5 cm in diameter. It presents as a painless lump in the 
breast. They are managed by excision via a submammary incision. Option C: Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in 
younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma 
phyllodes. It presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. They are usually 
mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin. Nipple 
retraction is not seen in this condition. Benign lesions can be treated with enucleation or wide 
local excision. Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant lesions are treated with a 
mastectomy. Option D: Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is a 
cystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected during 
lactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stopping 
breastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solid 
tumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes the 
lesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followed 
by excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele.

questions.question:
Question 10: A postmenopausal lady came to the clinic with complaints of breast pain and a lump in her 
right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears as shown in the image. 
What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.explanation:
In the given image, the orange peel-like appearance, also called as peau d’orange is caused by 
cutaneous lymphatic edema, due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is the hallmark 
of inflammatory carcinoma. Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin. Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction. Cancer-en-cuirasse is an aggressive form of cancer, where there is cutaneous and subcutaneous 
infiltration of the cancer cells. Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction 
do not indicate skin involvement.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 11: A middle-aged woman presented with a painless lump in the breast. Mammography done 
showed suspicious microcalcifications. USG-guided core biopsy revealed large cells with 
cytoplasmic mucoid globules and neighborhood calcifications. There is no invasion into the 
basement membrane and fibrovascular stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of large cells with cytoplasmic mucoid globules with an intact basement membrane, 
and neighborhood calcifications are characteristic of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). 213 
Sold by @itachibot Lobular carcinoma in-situ is usually detected as an incidental finding on evaluation of either a 
mass lesion or abnormalities on mammography. The slide below shows cytoplasmic mucoid globules seen in lobular carcinoma in situ. Option A: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) can have various histological appearances like solid, 
comedo, papillary cribriform, etc Option B: Histology of Paget’s disease of the breast shows the presence of large pale vacuolated 
cells (Paget cells) in the rete pegs of the epithelium. 214 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Histology of phyllodes tumor consists of nodules of proliferating stromal cells, that are 
covered by epithelium. This resembles a leaf and is hence termed as phyllodes.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is most likely in a woman with bilateral and multicentric breast 
lumps?
questions.explanation:
Bilaterality and multicentricity are most commonly associated with lobular carcinoma in situ 
(LCIS). LCIS occurs bilaterally in 50 - 70% of cases. Multicentricity is seen in 60 - 90% of patients with 
LCIS. Multicentricity refers to the occurrence of second breast cancer outside the breast quadrant of the 
primary cancer (or at least 4 cm away). Multifocality refers to the occurrence of a second cancer 
within the same breast quadrant as the primary cancer (or within 4 cm of it). 215 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 13: An annual screening mammogram done for a middle-aged woman showed clusters of 
microcalcifications. Stereotactic trucut biopsy revealed a comedo growth pattern. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of microcalcifications on mammography and comedo pattern on histology is 
suggestive of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Treatment: • Breast conservation surgery with radiotherapy or, • Simple mastectomy- least loco-regional recurrence • No role of chemotherapy • If ER, PR +ve- hormonal therapy 216 
Sold by @itachibot Comedo subtype refers to the presence of necrosis. It implies that the tumor cells are growing 
rapidly and the blood vessel is not able to supply all the malignant cells. On the contrary, 
non-comedo subtype implies that the tumor is growing slowly and the blood vessel is able to 
supply all the cells. Therefore, the comedo subtypes are of high-grade DCIS.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 14: A woman with BRCA1 gene mutation presented with lumps in both breasts and enlarged 
axillary lymphadenopathy. She gives a history of breast cancer in her sister. MRI and trucut 
biopsy done confirmed the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma of the breast. Which of the 
following statements is true regarding the given condition?

options.a: Lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia
options.b: It is a slow growing tumor
options.c: Tamoxifen can be used in the treatment
options.d: Has poorer prognosis than invasive lobular carcinoma

questions.explanation:
Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. Therefore, 
the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the 
cancer cells to the lymph nodes. Medullary carcinoma is a common type of breast cancer associated with BRCA1 gene mutation. 
Bilateral tumors are common when family history is present. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due 
to necrosis and hemorrhage. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative (ER/PR/Her-2 
negative). Histopathology consists of: • A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells • A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation It has a better prognosis than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 15: 208 
Sold by @itachibot A male patient who presented with a lump in his right breast is diagnosed to have breast 
carcinoma. Which of the following is true regarding the given condition?

options.a: The prognosis is worse than in females
options.b: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type
options.d: Tamoxifen is not effective in treatment

questions.explanation:
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer seen in men. Breast cancer in men accounts for less than 1% of all breast cancers. The peak incidence is 
between 60-70 years of age. Majority of the patients present with a hard mass in the 
breast. Important risk factors are: 217 
Sold by @itachibot • BRCA2 mutation • Radiation exposure • Estrogen therapy • Testicular feminizing syndrome • Klinefelter syndrome Diagnosis of male breast carcinoma is similar to females which involves a clinical examination, 
imaging, and tissue biopsy. Grading, treatment, and prognosis are the same as female breast 
cancer. The majority of male breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive and hence tamoxifen is 
used in the treatment.
questions.chapter_heading: Carcinoma Breast - Risk Factors and Types

questions.question:
Question 16: A 35-year-old woman is worried about developing breast cancer. Her mother and sister had 
developed breast cancer at the age of 30 years and 32 years respectively. She has 2 daughters. 
After evaluation, she is found to have a BRCA-1 gene mutation. Which of the following 
methods will you suggest for the maximum risk reduction of developing carcinoma breast in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Prophylactic mastectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy will provide maximum risk 
reduction in this patient with a complete family, a positive gene mutation, and positive family 
history. Breast cancer risk reduction techniques: • Lifestyle modification: Low-calorie diet, daily exercise, no smoking, no drinking, etc. • More frequent screening every 6-12 months with mammogram +- MRI • Chemoprevention: Preferred in women >35 years of age in patients who are ER/PR positive. 
Given for 5-10 years. • SERMS (selective estrogen receptor modulators) - Tamoxifen and raloxifene - have adverse 
effects. If a patient on tamoxifen develops abnormal uterine bleeding, the drug needs to be 
stopped. • Aromatase Inhibitors (AIs): Better tolerated than SERMs have a low risk of cardiovascular and 
endometrial complications. They are used only in post-menopausal women. • Risk-reduction surgeries: done in patients with gene mutations or patients with first-degree 
relatives with breast cancers. Provides >90% risk-reduction. Preferred in patients who have 
completed their family. Best results when done < 40 years of age. • Bilateral mastectomy • Salpingo-oophorectomy: preferred in patients with BRCA1/2 mutations to prevent the risk of 
ovarian cancer too. 218 
Sold by @itachibot Investigations in Breast diseases
